subject: Re: learning
msgSnippet: I would recommend that you try 15-minute sessions of practice. Overtaxing yourself at an early stage may result in frustration. Start with a few simple letters
messageBody:
I would recommend that you try 15-minute sessions of practice.
Overtaxing yourself at an early stage may result in frustration. Start
with a few simple letters & see if you can combine them into as many
words as you know (for instance, the QS letters #3, #23 & #26). Also,
use the 8 common abbreviations in your own personal written notes.

Don't feel that you need to learn everything all at once. By learning
the alphabet at your own speed, you'll gain a lot more enjoyment out
of it.

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "nerd_the_mighty"
<nerd_the_mighty@...> wrote:
>
> just a quik question would learning quickscript by copying a book
> until fluent be an effetive way of learning?
>
